value_name: numeral marker in a complex numeral
numeral marker in a complex numeral
comment: Source: Hajimurat, consultant on Kvankhidatli, asked by A. Zakirova. Only numerals in range 100—1000 were asked. It seems that Kvankhidatli Andi uses two linking suffixes in hundreds and thousands! Suffix -la is common with tens, but -k'eku is not used in tens. In my opinion [Maksim], -k'eku is supposed to be /k'ek'u/. The consultant said that this -k'eku means 'with something, too much'. Apparently, this is cognate with Karata -č'eku(b)!
example_as_in_source: чIе озиру-ла кIеку лъоб бешоно-ла кIеку ишту-цIо-ла чIе-гу гьинцIо
example: č'e oziru-la k'eku ɬob bešono-la k'eku ištu-c'o-la č'e-gu hinc'o
gloss: two thousand-LNK1 LNK2 three hundred-LNK1 LNK2 five-ten-LNK1 two-NUM stone
example_source: Hajimurat, consultant on Kvankhidatli, asked by A. Zakirova
example_comment: writing and transcription might be slightly inexact, by A. Zakirova in the field

value_name: numeral marker in a complex numeral
numeral marker in a complex numeral
comment: [magomedbekova1967: 41] mentions that in Southern Akhvakh cardinals do not inflect by class. It is unclear whether she means that the -CM suffix is absent in these cardinals. No examples are given. [creisselsdraft2020: 16], however, mentions that in Northern Akhvakh -CM (be) is omitted. He gives many examples, all of them without the class suffix. Also, [creisselsdraft2020: 17] shows examples of cardinals without the class marker which is present in examples shown in [magomedovaabdulaeva2007: 687]. This problem needs help.

numeral marker in a complex numeral
comment: If a simple cardinal has -no in the end, it is usually present when this cardinal is used as a component in a complex numeral. Exception: оцIино '10' but -no is lost in 11—19: уй-оцIи '14' (this is one model of derivation of 11—19, another would be оцIино уйно, which is reported to be used less frequently [alekseevetal1998: 299 {in the file}]). Also, хъу '20' does not have -no but it is attached in numerals 30—90: хъу-но сис '21'. It is apparently AND but then there's also this model for deriving tens: хъу-но-хъу '40', уй-но-хъу '80' (уй = 4). So kind of unclear. Good complex numeral examples are absent.
example_comment: Can not find a clearer example. (It is hard to understand whether the first -no here is AND or NUM but probably the latter.)

value_name: numeral marker in a complex numeral
comment: -no is lost in most numerals, preserved in stems 3, 5, 20. If these roots appear in a complex numeral, -no is always used with them, for example: qu-no õc’o '30', ħo-no bešon ‘300’. They are like a part of the root now (morphoids?), I guess. In Khwarshi, -no NUM is visibly different from the binding suffix -n(o)* AND, which is realised as -n (õc’o-n ũq’e ‘14’) or -un/-in (cf. the example). This looks like it could be a phonetic distribution, coinciding with lexical distribution (because the number of possible roots to attach to is not that large).
example_as_in_source: išt’ʷ-ac’a azar-in ẽɬ bešon-un q’ˤʷene-qu-n baƛ
example: išt’ʷ-ac’a azar-in ẽɬ bešon-un q’ˤʷene-qu-n baƛ
gloss: five-ten thousand-AND six hundred-AND two-twenty-AND eight
example_comment: išt’ʷ-ac’a is not a Khwarshi word; tens from 50 to 90 are borrowed from nearby Andic languages.

value_name: numeral marker in a complex numeral
comment: Simple numerals up to 10 (included) have -no. When used in a complex numeral, this -no is preserved, even in 11—19 (oc’e-no q’o-no ‘12’). If a component which does not have -no is inside a complex numeral, it attaches =no AND. Forker distinguishes between them using different signs (-/=) but gives no comment on how the distinction is made in the first place. Some irregularity happens with qu '20', though: it does not have -no but attaches it in q’o-no qu=no ‘40’, even though it is the last component here and there is nothing to link to.
example_as_in_source: ʡazal=no q’o-no bišon=no qu=no oc’e-no uq’i-no
example: ʡazal=no q’o-no bišon=no qu=no oc’e-no uq’i-no
gloss: thousand=AND two-NUM hundred=AND twenty=AND ten-NUM four-NUM

value_name: numeral marker in a complex numeral
comment: Simple numerals up to 20 (included) have -no (or eroded versions of it). When used in a complex numeral, this -no is preserved, even in 11—19 (ac’ə.n ɬa.na ‘13’). If a component which does not have -no is inside a complex numeral, it attaches -no AND. For example, -rig 'ten' (root used to make numerals 30—90) lacks -no when the numerals ends with it: ɬa.na=rig '30' but attaches -no when there is necessity to link something: ɬa.na=rig-no ɬi-no ‘35’.

value_name: numeral marker in a complex numeral
comment: Also look: [madieva1965: 105]. Simple numerals up to 20 (included) have -na. When used in a complex numeral, this -na is preserved, even in 11—19 (ацIо-на илъ-на ‘16’). If a component which does not have -na is inside a complex numeral, it attaches -na AND. For example, -йиг 'ten' (root used to make numerals 30—90) lacks -na when the numerals ends with it: илъ-на йиг '60' but attaches -na when there is necessity to link something: илъ-на йиг-на гьõс ‘61’.

value_name: numeral marker in a complex numeral
comment: -al generally does not repeat in complex numerals. However, it is used with the number of thousands (cf. кIе-л азир ‘2 000’). No examples on millions but I suppose it is also used with millions.

comment: -al generally does not repeat in complex numerals. However, it is used with the number of thousands (cf. example). No examples on millions but I suppose it is also used with millions.

value_name: numeral marker in a complex numeral
comment: Apparently, -al does not repeat in complex numerals. It appears at the end of all final components, including those ending with -ra but except ca '1'. It is unclear whether it is used with the number of thousands (as it is used in other Dargwa languages) because there are no such examples.
